Title: Implications of Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy for Psychosocial Functioning and Social Relationships of Transgender People

This project aims to investigate the effects of gender-affirming hormone therapy on the psychosocial functioning and social relationships of transgender people. Despite high rates of social disruption and suicide risk, there is a critical need to understand the causal pathways linking hormone therapy to improved outcomes in this population. Our study will employ a biopsychosocial model, incorporating a variety of novel and cutting-edge research methods across four work packages. We will isolate the causal pathways linking hormone therapy to psychosocial functioning, empower transgender individuals to share their personal and relational experiences, and inform policy and practice for gender identity services. Our informed consent model ensures the active participation and protection of transgender people throughout the research process. By focusing on improvement of psychosocial functioning and social relationship outcomes, this project will contribute to the forefront of gender-affirming healthcare. Our findings will have significant implications for the development of evidence-based interventions, services, and policies that support the health and well-being of transgender individuals. Ultimately, this project seeks to improve the lives of transgender people, promoting greater social inclusion and reducing health disparities in this marginalized population.

Title: Implications of Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy for Psychosocial Functioning and Social Relationships of Transgender People

This proposal seeks to investigate the effects of gender-affirming hormone therapy on the psychosocial functioning and social relationships of transgender individuals. Our project addresses this gap by employing a biopsychosocial model and a variety of novel and cutting-edge research methods across four work packages.

Our aims are threefold: to isolate the causal pathways linking hormone therapy to psychosocial functioning, to empower transgender individuals to voice their personal and relational experiences, and to inform policy and practice for gender identity services. Our informed consent model ensures the active participation and agency of transgender people throughout the research process.

This study's outcomes will focus on improving psychosocial functioning and social relationship outcomes for transgender individuals. By positioning ourselves at the forefront of gender-affirming healthcare research, we aim to contribute meaningfully to the development of evidence-based practices that promote the well-being and resilience of transgender people. Our findings will have significant implications for healthcare providers, policymakers, and transgender individuals themselves, ultimately enhancing the quality of life and social inclusion of this marginalized population.
